Cedric Beust wrote:

> Unit testing allows you to test very small portions of code in order to
> catch failures as soon as possible.  If all you test is public/protected
> methods, you will miss an opportunity to catch a bug in a very fundamental
> piece of your code and you will be wasting time looking for it.

It has been my experience that most programmers, including myself, write 
too much code. That is, we write code covering cases that simply cannot 
happen. The more code you have the more bugs you have. Removing code is 
one of the surest ways to remove bugs, not to mention save time.

The discipline required to write all tests exclusively through public 
interfaces often reveals that the code is not in fact behaving the way 
one thinks it is. Code is not activated that seems like it should be. 
Code paths don't flow the way one expects. Sometimes the mere act of 
trying to test a particular piece of private code and failing reveals 
the bugs.

It is critical, though, that you use code coverage tools like Cobertura 
and Clover to actually see what's being tested. That way you know 
whether or not you're actually testing the inner, private parts of your 
code. What's really interesting is when you discover that a piece of 
code you thought was being tested isn't. That discovery often reveals a 
bug that the test themselves weren't finding.

Finally, a separate reason for limiting the tests to the public (and 
protected) interfaces is the same as the reason for keeping some code 
private in the first place. This allows you to change algorithms and 
implementations freely without worrying about breaking the tests. More 
importantly, it tells you that if you make a change and the tests break, 
it really is a bug. When you're testing the private parts directly, 
major changes are expected to break tests and require the tests to be 
modified. Thus it stops being obvious whether test breakage signals a 
regression or a test problem.

In my test suites, I test only what I'm willing to guarantee. The tests 
become contracts. They are even more than the API documentation the 
promise of what my software will support. And I'm only willing to 
promise to support the public and protected APIs.

It is worth noting that most of my work, especially the most tested 
parts of my work, takes the form of libraries rather than client or 
server applications. Possibly the distinction between unit and 
acceptance testing is a little weaker here. Many end user applications 
don't really provide any published API at all. Nonetheless I suspect 
that even in purely internal APIs it makes sense to distinguish between 
what's guaranteed to be supported and what's merely a means to an end 
that may change as necessary to optimize or refactor a code base. Tests 
should only touch the stable, guaranteed parts.
